conclusion: A beam of blue light travels from point A in the air, crosses the boundary between air and water, and passes through point B in the water.
The boundary is represented by the solid horizontal line.
Point O is the intersection of the line AB and the boundary.
Point O1 is the point where the incident ray from A meets the boundary before refraction into the water.
In the first figure, the dashed line from A to O represents the path of light before refraction.
In the second figure, the incident ray from A meets the boundary at point O1, which is slightly to the right of point O.
After refraction, the light bends and passes through point B in the water.
When light travels from air (less dense medium) into water (denser medium), it bends toward the normal due to refraction.
The angle of incidence i (at point O1) is larger than the angle of refraction r.
